title: What does being appointed a legal representative of an estate mean?
question: My husband's great grandfather passed a couple months ago and we are now going through probate court.There is one member of the family who is trying to just take everything for herself and they want to make her the legal respresentative for the estate; however, what does that mean?What rights does that give her vs the rest of the family?Does that mean she is going to get everything or does it mean she will be the one in charge of the estate?
answers: Legal representative, executor, personal representative are all terms that refer to an individual who is appointed by the Probate court to take charge of administering someone's estate. This person is not necessarily a beneficiary of the estate. The executor must still comply with any instructions left in the decedent's Will about how assets are to be distributed to the beneficiaries. If there was no Will, the beneficiaries will be determined by the State's default rules under the Intestate Succession Statute. Generally, spouses are first in line to inherit any community property and a portion of the separate property. If there is no spouse, then children are next in line. If you would like more specific advice, please contact my office at (800) 818-3954 for a complimentary consultation.

Someone who is "trying to take everything for herself" should not be appointed the representative of an estate. Your husband needs to consult with an attorney.

If you would like to obtain legal advice about your situation, I am available to consult with you at your convenience. The initial consultation (30 minutes) is free. If you would like my assistance, please contact me at 916 925-6005.

The "personal representative of the estate" is a generic term to describe the person administering the estate. If there is a will, and the person administering the estate is nominated in the will, the person is the "executor." If there is no will, or if the person administering the estate was not nominated in the will, then the person is an "administrator." In either event, the role of the personal representative is a fiduciary role, and his or her job is to collect the assets, pay the debts, and distribute the property (typically with court supervision) to the beneficiaries who are to receive it under the decedent's will or the laws of intestate succession if there was no will.

If you are concerned that the person seeking to take control is not fit to serve, or would not comply with her fiduciary duties, you should object to her petition for appointment. You should consider consulting with an experienced probate attorney in the county in which the estate is being administered for more specific advice targeted on your situation.

When a person dies with a will, the executor must file a petition with the register of wills or with the probate court, depending on the state of residence procedures, to probate the will. If a person dies without a will, then the next of kin must petition the court or go to the register of wills to obtain letters of administration. Once that person has received letters testatmentary or letters of administration, the executor or administrator can then act for the estate. This will allow that person to transfer assets to the beneficiaries of the estate once the estate administration has taken care of all debts, administration costs, taxes, etc.
The executor has a fiduciary duty to preserve assets and follow the terms of the will. It does not allow the executor to take estate assets, they pass by the will. Having said that if you believe that this person cannot be trusted you need to strongly object by retaining estate counsel to challenge the person named as being unfit. You need to do this immediately if you have a strong feeling that this person cannot be trusted. If you wait and that person does in fact loot or steal from the estate you may be out of luck. Get with an estates attorney to discuss your concerns and to protect your interests.
